Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with "implacement," and the second with "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture creates a more grounded community. (That is a very rough summary—a disclaimer just in case my professor or any classmate happens to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.

Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then—nor am I now—a math person. I hate math. I am math-phobic. You get the picture. So as I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited practical joker.

The GOP gets scolded over recruitment. Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy.  

The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table—a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies.  

But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time, making all the new voters members of the GOP. All of it seemed suspicious to Linda Cross, who was there to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing—I have nothing negative to say about this game, as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exceed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash-free, plenty of story/content to keep you engaged, with options for each day like multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing MyCareer, and so far, it's a 10/10. The facescan worked really well for me (though I used it twice—the first one gave me a Down syndrome forehead...). Keep in mind, using the MyNBA2K17 app lets you facescan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Magic fans, beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game—one meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, and gold is essential. It's so important that they've implemented a daily cap, which is understandable since gold unlocks everything in-game. But prepare for a long and tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even chat with. If you choose to play for free, expect to spend roughly four hours a day, alone, for over a month just to unlock the cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate prequels since they technically go backward in a story rather than forward (this is an issue for every prequel). Granted, it offers more story-wise. The combat feels sloppy and not as sharp as Arkham City managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story unaffected). Some gadgets are placed at a ridiculous hotkey, forcing your hand to travel across the whole keyboard to reach them. It might sound minor, but in combat, it could potentially break your combo.

They basically fixed *Shadow Warrior* (2013). The boss fights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as *D44M*'s, but still solid), and enemies aren't too spongy—unless you're careless with handling elemental and upgrade mechanics. The upgrade system is well-balanced and not too tedious once you get the hang of it. The elemental effects and limited ammo gently encourage you to switch between weapons. There are lots of cool, unique weapons (key word here, unlike *Borderlands*' RNG-based formula) that remain viable for most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's tracks.

So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know how to start this review. This all relates to my career. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m, has maxed stats, and already has all the necessary perks. Okay, and now tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person’s height? Why can’t someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I’m 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height, and noticed I couldn’t reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game tell me this before I create a character, or even when I hit the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts—ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, etc. I also felt much more attached to this character. The story starts out extremely rough but gets much better as you play (I think this is true for every AC game, personally). Edward was quite an interesting character, and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this AC game, which I never got from any of the previous ones—maybe because they seemed to have a bigger purpose. They definitely weren’t required, but they were fun to get, and the rewards felt very balanced.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn’t absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, as long as you have the money to purchase gun parts—which is my main complaint with this game: it’s pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, since the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is an excellent idea. I’d take this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you’re alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you’re like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it’s not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death can lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus, the aiming reticle is on the small side, and the zoom is underpowered.  

With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up gameplay is great. I've been playing it as often as I can—just one more mission, just one more supply run, or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great—I’m not sure exactly how many there are, but there’s a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining too—no, I’m not kidding. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or if you’re new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to master it. Don’t get upset; you’ll lose a lot of units. Just make sure to plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was negatively biased toward this game before I played it. I wasn’t even sure about buying it. I don’t know, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me, even though I like science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s not cheesy (okay, sometimes it’s cheesy). And the different story characters all have their own sense of humor. Those characters really do have distinct personalities. And the level design? It’s just rad. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I’m planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn’t played the sequel.

Okay, let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-), then my thoughts on this game.  
+ Some of the best characters  
+ Good story  
+ Lots of content  
+ Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like)  
+ You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest)  
- Bad graphics (I don’t think graphics really matter anyway)  
- Weird and awkward love scenes  
- Invisible walls  
- There’s one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes  
-/+ This isn’t really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist (the one you made) can’t talk.  

Now for my thoughts: I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs—or games in general—I’ve ever played. So if you’re an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done—transforming mid-fight is often a necessity and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent *War for/Fall of Cybertron* games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, though some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

So I downloaded the game and played it for a little while, but it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing the game. There's a bug where it says there was an update to the terms of service, and every time you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. That isn't too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that even necessary? It's also irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it's just okay. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4K+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if you're new to the series. Just keep in mind there's lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keyboard/mouse setup—both are fully rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half the DLC is included for free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended for all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No-commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at launch, and after all these patches it runs really well. In my opinion, this is a genuinely great and fun game, though the format can be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with enemies each time you progress the story). I especially enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as Batman + one other character), and the ability to use a controller for most parts of the game while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including during APC commander chases, is actually quite enjoyable once you learn to use the brakes to skid around corners—and once you master that, cruising through the city becomes truly satisfying!

Damn fine FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great—excellent FPS mechanics, a solid story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint of heart, though—some of those cutscenes were pretty darn brutal and vivid. But when a game is this good overall, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here's what I noticed:  

- No SLI support—WTF? I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my card since it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a decent single-GPU card.  
- Frustratingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language—I am Dutch. So please excuse any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories:  

- Graphics  
- Controls  
- Sound  
- Gameplay  
- Replayability  

**Graphics:** The game has a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick, with no unnecessary details. The color schemes are nice, and it totally works for this game. You can set the graphics to 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory—it runs smoothly on Windows 8.1.  

**Controls:** The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, or with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I’ve put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don’t buy this game thinking it’s like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It’s a game in its own class and should be treated as such. Can’t tell you how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, God forbid you get shot in the face and die. It’s not like that doesn’t happen in real life or anything.  

Edit: Okay, so I’ve been playing this game for a while now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best MP games around. A good thing to play when you’re not feeling CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and dying from this game—it's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story/world has me hooked, and the puzzles are fun. But the best part, beyond everything else, is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the jokes, parodies, and references. Even if you've never played an RPG before, you'll still enjoy the humor. If you've played *Final Fantasy VII* or *X*, you absolutely need to play this game—without spoiling too much, I had to stop after two hours just to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry—I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I just didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution didn't work for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this one completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still didn't find the gameplay fun. It also lacks a pause button—or if it has one, I never found it. Considering many sequences are timed, this feels like a critical oversight. I also think this game has more cutscenes than actual gameplay, leaving me drumming my fingers too often.

This game... phew, where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful—from the story to the graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn’t just any story; it actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the tale my character was telling. The gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or a second game, I’d be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this—you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory.' In previous games, you progressed through Earth's timeline, advancing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. However, in this game, you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a fresh approach by introducing new mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. What I didn’t enjoy was that these new mechanics could sometimes feel overwhelming. One improvement I’d suggest is incorporating new artwork, such as the environment you see when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror—you must save your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. Also, I find the zombies to feel very natural and well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or talk with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend/enjoy this game because, from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game-breaking issues:  

- No Australian servers - A single red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering/lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Combine that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game.  

- Everything artifacts like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my overclock. I set my GPU back to stock settings, and sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't very deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is filled to the brim, and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is just the right amount of challenging, though it leans more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas creates a good sense of progression.

To the Moon" is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's *The Walking Dead* is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for *To the Moon*! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay isn’t the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I didn’t care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well, and it definitely doesn’t intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the *Doctor Who* references are endless.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game with a truly great storyline. Set after a calamity, you begin rebuilding on the bastion. The game offers plenty of choices—what to build for an advantage, which weapons to use, what power-ups to equip on them, and even which drinks to consume for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant colors that prove the apocalypse doesn’t have to be dull. Best of all, the game features dynamic narration based on your actions. For example, if you pick up a weapon and then swap it in the armory, the narration might comment on your choice of the new weapon.

I originally bought this game in early development when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree.' That was when the game was good. All the guns at that point were equally overpowered, so there were no balance issues—everyone could kill anyone at any time. Also, the game used to give you unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd think for a game with 'bajillions of guns,' they'd at least give you more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before making you pay for more. At one point, I had about three pages worth of guns and was planning new ideas for more because, personally, that's where I found the fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews for certain products that can be misleading. In this case, the reviews truly reflect the fun of this neat little game. It’s an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn’t typically like in other MOBA games. I expected this trend to continue but decided to try a melee tank anyway. The outcome pleasantly surprised me, and I ended up trying more characters as they unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat encounter, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it's so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the changes to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better—and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story follows Dante as he’s introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with so much detail—it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It knows when to be serious but isn’t afraid of funny moments. The character design is spot-on, featuring a diverse cast with unique personalities and hidden depths. It stands out from other RPGs because you don’t have to kill anyone—a rare concept in the genre. Drawing heavy inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I’ve ever played, it’s clear this game is something special. Plus, it easily has the best soundtrack I’ve heard in years.

I’m recommending this solely because it’s free and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor—I wasn’t shocked nor emotionally moved in any way. Maybe I’m desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction from me. The other half of the game tries to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other things. In theory, it’s a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that’s with reading and absorbing every bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you explore it. It's a brilliant way to challenge your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't heavily story-driven, it did give rise to one of the most popular and well-received games of 2011. I still play and complete this game when I'm feeling bored, and I love returning to see what birthed a legend and what makes a legend.  

Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain, at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game—one you press directly and another that requires placing a cube on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only had two: one minor and the other quite annoying) — edit: both bugs are resolved, and one fix increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120 — and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX 480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range, though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and getting 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to being one of my personal favorite RTS games. Combine this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode, and it hits the spot. I’m not (read: try not to be) overly biased just because this game lets you turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning all at the same time. Honestly, I do like complicated RTS games nowadays—think Civ V and so on. However, such games tend to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one overly complicated game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is pleasant, but when paired, they craft truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic, heartbreaking to hopeful—sometimes all at once—while flipping RPG tropes on their head. And all this without even touching on the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I’ve only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have turned an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There’s a fairly steep learning curve to the game’s mechanics, which I’m still trying to master; however, this depth of strategy offers countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is nearly infinitely replayable. I find myself engrossed in every session I play, no matter how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those enjoyable initial hours, you'll start to notice that the only thing left the game offers is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is that the developers work hard and provide semi-frequent updates, which often include substantial content—from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems to new Warframes and other tweaks or features. It's a good game to play casually, though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you really enjoy grinding. The upside is that the game is free, so I'd recommend trying it out. If you're looking for a quick fix, give it a shot.

This game is so... very... boring. I bought it because I believed it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a popular and fun PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you go around absorbing ever bigger things to grow larger and absorb even bigger things. But the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels aren't inventive, and what's there is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show—rather, one that makes you feel depressed and question whether being alive is all it's cracked up to be. Every "living" creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off by saying you need to pick a side: Republican or Democrat—there's no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I’ll give the game credit—the character customization, though limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It’s the only time you get the option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was better. Settlements disrupt the narrative to the point where you'll resent babysitting them instead of progressing the story. Some keys are hardcoded and can't be rebound. Bugs are rampant—my Pip-Boy vanished permanently at one point, forcing me to look up console commands to restore it. Power armor requires little effort; it's practically handed to you early on, and fusion cores are abundant in shops, greatly diminishing its value compared to earlier Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and most aspects of this game are average—except for its stability, which far surpasses Fallout 3's frequent crashes. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Better than New Vegas? No. This title was massively overhyped for how disappointing it truly is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review):  
- 8.6 hours to reach the end  
- 10 collectibles found out of 25  
- Zero achievements out of 15  

What I liked:  
- Visuals up until the last level (ice caves)  
- The story isn't great, but the ending (after the credits) made me not regret spending time on this game  

What I disliked:  
- Visuals in the last level are uninteresting  
- Gameplay in the last level becomes much harder, turning into a frustrating experience of repetition  
- Achievements are too hard—13 out of 15 have been achieved by less than 2.1% of players

Pros:  
+ Good graphics  

Cons:  
- Bugs (especially in the environment—you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy)  
- The game handholds/babysits you too much  
- Dumb AI  
- Enemies always seem to know your location once you're spotted  
- Frustrating godlike accuracy by enemies, similar to the first Ghost Warrior  
- Terrible checkpoints and save system  
- Boring story that I couldn't care less about  

I wouldn't recommend it unless it's 90% off—even then, playing this game feels like a tedious chore. I'm only finishing it to move on to the next game in my library. Given how much time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and left me feeling liberated when I finished), I probably won't play this one to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game—servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar.  

While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: *"Go on, take the money and run! Uh uh uhhh! Go on, take the money and run!"* https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54  

--- English - 73 minutes playing the game. OMFG, just an hour in and this game is awesome! Some guns are OP, and matchmaking can be unfair sometimes, but hey, BF3's matchmaking is worse—newbies paired with high-level players who weren’t even real humans. You shoot them in the face, and nothing happens!

Who wouldn’t want to wear a fez? :D This puzzle-platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting bits to form a cube while navigating through a fairly large, branching map. The game is quite amusing, and playing through it to completion was a lot of fun. ^_^ It can get semi-frustrating if you aim for all the cubes and achievements, though. To collect every cube, you’ll need to crack codes that require deciphering—some may take seconds, while others might push you to check a guide (*raises hand* I gave up. -_-). The guide, "A Complete Guide to FEZ!!!

It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-scale games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scale of its universe, but I also felt that same scale was a hindrance to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too much for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. But I don't have either, and there are plenty more VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it's just a graze. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required to stay on target. There's no magical ammunition pool—if you reload halfway through your magazine constantly, you'll end up with a pouch full of half-empty mags. You can't run forever; sprint for too long, and your aim will suffer as you gasp for breath until you recover. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out—I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved it, however; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right.  

As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game runs pretty well for me on medium settings, and I'm using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. At first, the game defaulted to high settings and ran a bit sluggishly—not unplayably so, but switching to medium smoothed things out.  

I’m not sure if I’m just lucky when it comes to game issues, but many of the negative reviews sound like they’re coming from overly entitled people.

+RPG leveling +Wide variety of ship types +Physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +Easy-to-learn resource management +Dark humor -Grind-intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) -Subpar AI teammates -Low variety of equipment types -Low variety of leveling skills (no branching)  

Listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite the minuses above, there's still plenty of variety and strategy to enjoy. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even with limited equipment variety, it feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to extend the game's lifespan is through mods. *Fight for Universe* is easily the standout, but *Big Fight for Beef* is also great.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government and state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run parallel with the WEF's more upscale event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a dispute over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payout. The US firm is believed to be offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the arrangement. It has argued the deal was invalidated by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal stemmed from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticised the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have spoken out against the war. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4's *Thought for the Day* segment, he criticized the allocation of "billions" to war efforts instead of using those funds to lift people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The cardinal declared that 2005 should be the year to campaign to "make poverty history.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression—fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It stated that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up at night to browse the web. More significantly, the report argues that broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos heads back to US courts as the Russian oil and gas company continues its fight for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, aiming to use international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state-owned oil firm Rosneft after the auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now claim the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that acquires its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to the Blog Awards site as voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming 'blog' the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to halt construction of one of its giant dams, according to Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, reported the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News said the company may instead opt to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to cease construction at two other projects—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order.

Man City 0-2 Man Utd: Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more labored than patient, and they managed to fashion just one chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons'—the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr. Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda."  

Dr. Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi in the Upper Afan Valley before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the biggest problems Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. 'That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football—end-to-end with lots of good passing,' said the Old Trafford boss. 'We showed great character and guts, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do.' Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. 'Roy came on and brought composure to the midfield, which we needed and no other player could provide.'

Singer's film to show at festival: A documentary that takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10–20 February. It features the singer discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also attend. The 93-minute film includes Michael reflecting on his early days in Wham! as well as his later career, covering his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart: Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart incorporates data from music download sales, which were previously only tracked in a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two on Billboard's Pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be included in the UK singles chart later this year.  

Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. A second new chart—the Pop 100—also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay data to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard. The net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for Chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems while still continuing operations.  

Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club.  

"It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself."  

Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

Economy focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at No. 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that Labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle 'yob culture,' and the Lib Dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run AAA's in Sheffield. Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European Indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m rankings at the moment, with Cragg occupying the top spot.

Robinson aims for dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has set his sights on achieving victories in both codes against Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final.  

'Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league,' said Robinson.  

England have the opportunity to secure their third autumn international victory after consecutive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as avenging June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end a 34-year winless streak against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible because it uses an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams trying to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email currently circulating. The message's subject line reads 'Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal,' and its text bears the poor grammar and bad spelling typical of many phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids. Iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, stating it aims to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab, and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry stated that it aims to increase Iraq's 'very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years.' It also hopes to develop a 'highly visible and adaptable telecommunications sector.' Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. It is also planning a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to internet security, as older people and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for internet security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse range of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those purchasing home internet security programs are retired. Over the last three years, this figure has increased by an average of 13.2%. However, more retired women (53%) bought security software than retired men. The research reflects shifting stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks that high-speed broadband connections can pose to internet users.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music player can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called 'podcasting,' and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, though you do not need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show that podcasters create, usually from the comfort of their own home. They only need a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, and others can download and listen to them—all for free.

Levy wins Whitbread Novel Prize  
Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has seen her book *Small Island* win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean has claimed the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*.  

All category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which comes with a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal—which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction—has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie, with two early goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister then added the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to extend Hearts' lead. Craig Easton pulled one back with a contentious goal after an hour, but Hearts held firm.  

The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out. McAllister delivered the free kick into the box, where Miller outjumped the static Livingston defense to loop his header over Meldrum from 10 yards. Just 10 minutes in, the hosts doubled their advantage when Mikoliunas raced down the right and crossed for McAllister to head home at the far post.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service that will allow customers requiring significant computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzzphrase in a company that believes computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz. 'Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?' he asked in a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots. Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson was speaking ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie. Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, *Beyond the Sea*, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri)  
Headingley  
Friday, 25 February, 20:00 GMT  

The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphaël Ibañez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre.  

Friday’s game at Headingley got the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection.  

**Leeds:** Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham.  
**Replacements:** Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future—the fixed-line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It revealed that people keep their fixed-line phone because call charges are lower, but most respondents said the future was definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, often between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

Melzer shocks Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was often bamboozled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. 'I had a good game plan and executed it perfectly,' he said. 'It's always tough to come out and play Andre. I didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court.'

MPs tout Lords replacement plan: A group of MPs has tried to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Disappointed Scott in solid start: Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid.  

"It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete.  

The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third.  

Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 seconds but ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), claiming its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge signals the printer to refill even when unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the U.S. who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt users to replace them. However, the suit argues the chips also deactivate the cartridges on a preset date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website which enables the service.  

James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove.  

Mr. Cridland said: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music is on the Isle of Wight bill. Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, along with Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10–12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*, with other hits including *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the Aid Match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid Match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also part of the Northern squad. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. 'I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players,' he said. The match will give Woodward a chance to evaluate some of his options before announcing his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. 'The game promises to be a great spectacle,' he added.

Spirit Awards hail *Sideways*—the comedy *Sideways* has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for *Maria Full of Grace*.

Prince was crowned 'top music earner' in 2004, earning more than any other pop star, beating artists like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties with his *Musicology* tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global *Re-Invention* tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel ranked 10th, with their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year.  

"Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour grossed $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, *Musicology*.

Irish band U2 have been honoured at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by boy band Blue. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ Music Awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. US band Maroon 5 was named best new international artist and took the best international song title for *This Love*. More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French: 'I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you—it's at the Côte d'Azur I feel at home.'

The Tories outlined policing plans under which local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, as proposed by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He stated that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems argued the plan could allow extreme groups to run policing, while Labour criticised "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential that operational independence be retained. Jan Berry said: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.

At a glance: Tory health checks  
The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan:  
People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU who plan to stay six months or more—and are from a country with high TB rates—would require a chest X-ray and further tests if needed.  
All non-EU nationals intending to stay a year or longer would undergo a full medical examination, covering tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa refusal, while other conditions would be assessed case by case.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes. Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as 'one of the great performances of the past three decades.' Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it 'one of the most surreal games I have ever played in.' A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: 'There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.'

Doves soar to UK album summit: Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single *Black and White Town*, which reached number six.  

R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher.  

The latest Elvis Presley re-release, *(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame*, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop performer Akon's *Locked Up* is at number five, while hotly tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with *Oh My God*.

Davies favours Gloucester future. Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but that he would prefer to remain where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. But the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was unhappy with how he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some 'pretty frank discussions' with fellow ministers over the plans. But he stressed that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England limit next year's council tax increases to below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford added that nearly all central government departments have an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa: Four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are all set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin are the first Arab side ever to compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to Israel recently after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and are based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethic and is a high-profile promoter of peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll'—more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, states that reducing the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003. He estimates this would save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate, included in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a change could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be externally controlled by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user equilibrium (UE)-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level consists of a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model accounting for a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond pushing increasingly larger and more tangible objects into the quantum regime, this capability has spurred ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as for precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to broader classes of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals highlighted the possibility of overcoming this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. While experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have not yet achieved nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer product evaluations to help customers make decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have developed increasingly subtle and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they can change rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and, more critically, often remain unknown. Additionally, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which does not fully align with the goal of preserving the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete based on their practical objectives, not solely on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game result in stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity (UH-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control the transfer fidelity, the excited-state population, and robustness. We defined a measure of robustness for UH-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which the infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses was found to surpass that of Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share a common structural form that partially identifies the true mixture's component centers.
