Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component or fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components, without overlap. Our results hold when the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and remain valid even if the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we derive sharper results in terms of how they scale with the separation between components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( x_m \) in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) inside it by a dual group \( g^t \). In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence for the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was developed based on existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy during a race process with a nonlinear description of the mass center's libration movement, aiming to reproduce walk-run transition behavior. The experimental results for different speed regimes indicate that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a relevant quantity for quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences department, and laboratories of Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on time regularization, which preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. We employ a high-order MVS scheme, enabling large time steps when far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm can resolve near-exact collisions (with separations as small as a fraction of a physical radius) while maintaining the same time step as in weakly perturbed systems like the Solar System. We test the long-term behavior on systems of six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Comparisons with hybrid methods like Mercury show that our algorithm achieves superior energy conservation at equivalent computational cost.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator is guaranteed to yield positive results for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a far richer multipolar structure, offering a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. We present numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates can only impose mild constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the LISA space mission will refine these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs that evolve over time is a challenging task in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario where edges can represent short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans, which can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. Since temporal attention drives feature propagation between nodes, using node interaction dynamics to learn this key component offers greater flexibility while avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw, for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw is designed for near-field atom trapping, this research establishes a foundation for assessing potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near pcw surfaces. Longer-term goals include achieving strong atom-mediated coupling between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the pcw's gms, enabling quantum-level optomechanics with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences split into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects cause a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression represent a significant source of uncertainty for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to rapidly predict the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ΛCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those captured in child-centered recordings, have been shown to be among the most challenging audio files to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such diverse conditions would be highly valuable for language acquisition studies, where researchers examine the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and assessing remediation effects. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network that classifies audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations from other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows framing the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing—governing the shape of the density and thus potentially the modal structure—is crucial to identifying the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naïve interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, restoring sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated exclusively by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often viewed data analyses with a causal objective unfavorably. The introduction of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). A clear classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and methods required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that failing to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis contributes to widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard understanding is that these particles ensure extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it remains unclear what goes wrong if this condition fails. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on supersymmetry or a specific UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurements establish ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful platform for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models used in many application areas such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to their intuitive appeal for modeling. Despite ODEs' wide usage in modeling, the frequent absence of analytic solutions makes it difficult to estimate ODE parameters from data, especially when the model has many variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on the equations of a numerical solver. It enables fast estimation by avoiding computations of a full numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational Bayes method, more specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry-broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an $s$-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential—i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, and this approach has been used in numerous applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied without surface flashover. However, a concern regarding this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity exhibits only a very slow decrease of approximately 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the idea of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. In addition, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of the Chern-Simons vector fields living on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons and allows them to continuously transform into one another in a natural way. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically study how the superposition of both effects impacts the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface creates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson currents, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. of Turbul. 2020), that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small, fast-moving cores and another family of larger, slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. Typically, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several CTQW-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving the hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from \(o(n^5)\) to \(o(n^2\log n)\). Moreover, our methods also exponentially improve the precision dependence of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm by Chakraborty et al. for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the main EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: (wet) EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and subsequently drives them to migrate toward the MBH—this process boosts the EMRI formation rate in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them—no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under these circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract users immediately so they decide to stay on the website and become active. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category and is crucial to a company's development and even survival. Existing work on user cold-start recommendation either requires additional user effort, such as setting up an interview process, or relies on side information [10], such as user demographics, locations, or social relations. However, users may be unwilling to participate in interviews, and side information for cold-start users is often unavailable.

Deep learning has solved many problems beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often results in a challenging nonlinear problem for which the optimal solution is impractical to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, DeepRx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline—from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits—in a 5G-compliant manner. We enable accurate channel estimation by carefully constructing the convolutional neural network's input using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can result in wasted fuzzing effort due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers include distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing both the number and cumulative size of seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we systematically explore. We present results from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact on finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups, in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template, a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed, regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach employs, for the first time in the field of ENF, a temporal window—not necessarily a rectangular one—at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are utilized for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results in terms of both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to provide a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques for the Python ecosystem as a single, consistent package. The included dimension reduction methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced-dimension spaces are provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also includes classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation tools. Finally, direpack has been designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to be seamlessly integrated into statistical and/or machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation. This increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used to improve the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We compare our approach with frequentist methods relying on numerical integration, showing that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example from a business establishment survey demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developments combining traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, bridging these two rich but distinct sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others—have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The 'Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials' special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence of a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other within a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also revealed two orientational relaxation processes: the first arises from rotation of the side mesogenic groups, while the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these approaches is to employ an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may cause an increasing number of hash bits to become trapped in the wrong saturated regions of the activation functions without recovery. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization losses can further exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (often termed "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity is raised to \(e_f\) after the gas disc disperses due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). In a slight variation of this scenario, narrower belts can form if the planetesimals initially possess eccentricity, which may arise from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could also result from instabilities that enhance the disc eccentricity, without requiring the presence of any planets.

An electron is typically considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it possess more due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been experimentally observed beyond this linear regime. Here, we report measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We observe two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that intensify as the wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by adjusting the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to data provided by the $Gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between globular clusters and the known merging events experienced by the Milky Way. $methods$. To this end, we combined kinematic information from $Gaia$ for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages available, after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package that implements novel, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. Specifically, the methods included in this package are the *two-nn*, *gride*, and *hidalgo* models. To make these new estimators easily accessible, the package provides a few high-level, intuitive functions built upon a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. *Intrinsic* includes models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category comprises the *two-nn* and *gride* models. The functions dedicated to these methods perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category includes *hidalgo*, a Bayesian mixture model for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, which promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results of the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO to current pulse stimulation, the handwritten digit recognition task demonstrates that an RC system using a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in image classification. Additionally, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be effectively solved by a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs, as confirmed in second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the greater the share of overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect arises in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked by popularity. We analytically demonstrate that the few-get-richer effect emerges when users tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for item classes. Through simulations, we examine how the strength of the effect varies with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also experimentally test our predictions in an online study with human participants. Our findings have important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across various platforms. However, most pruning techniques essentially trade off model accuracy and regularity, resulting in compromised inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension—pattern-based sparsity—which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity, achieving both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. With carefully designed patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction capability across different DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework simultaneously performs pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally aligns with compiler optimizations for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs substantially from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events affecting the groups differently. Constructing a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall control group may reduce this bias. We examine this phenomenon through simulation studies. Specifically, we investigate the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For this analysis, we created a more closely matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval that includes substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for use in simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models' ability to reproduce the data. This can be done through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) simulating multiple reproductions of the original study using the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is generally straightforward to apply. Here we consider applying the method to time-to-event data and examine the special case when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential schemes are presented. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on both repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can enable: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predicting the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing the filter functions driving the designed quantum sensor in the frequency domain. The accomplishment of these tasks will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point, we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try to overcome it.  

To start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, *What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?*

I can’t think of anyone who has just one interest in life and wants to do only that for the rest of their life. [The way we work] Around 15 percent of American workers don’t have traditional full-time jobs. They’re part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term 'side hustle' fits this ethos, where people combine a few different things to make a living. The word 'side hustle' has its roots in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used 'hustle' to refer to a kind of scam. By the 1950s, they used 'side hustle' to describe legitimate work as well. A side hustle is a little different from a second job. A second job is about necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her. Michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information required for every other cell to function and to replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the Industrial Revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people say that if you get nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked? Like, it’s supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking—picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. We’re working really hard to move past stuff like that, so we need a new way to deal with stage nerves. And I realized what I’d really like is to look at you as much as you’re looking at me—just to even things out a little. So if I had way more eyeballs, we’d all be really comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." It's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it? Often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus—though you know how these things go; he probably never said it. What I'm interested in, though, is—is it true? I mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving, or possibly for live-tweeting at a TED Talk as well. But I'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once—or three or even four—is exactly what we should be aiming for. Look no further than Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.

I know this is going to sound strange, but I think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and when I was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home when I was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build... a robot. A robot.

Sustainability represents the what, the where, and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what’s important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how I impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water’s bounty for their livelihood. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood that we’re so fortunate to eat. So what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These elements of his work kept his audience eager for more. When first published, his stories were serialized, appearing a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals before being reprinted as books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us like an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (Applause)  

Bhakti Sharma: Imagine, in the scorching Rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. Twenty minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.

I'm going to talk about a technology we're developing at Oxford now, which we believe will change how computer games and Hollywood movies are made. That technology is simulating humans—simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Before I discuss this further, let's take a quick look at what human characters currently look like in computer games. This is a clip from a game called *Grand Theft Auto 3*, which we briefly saw yesterday. What you can see is—it's actually a very good game, one of the most successful of all time.

Like many people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were obsessed with the Women's World Cup held in France. Here we were, watching these incredible athletes—the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging—and at the same time, outside the field, these women were advocating for equal pay, and in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the U.S. was the best place for us to start. It wasn’t until a few games into the tournament that a friend turned to me and said, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is commercials for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's begin with a story about a culture that lived in Micronesia in the early 1900s, called the Yap. I want to tell you about the Yap because their form of money is truly fascinating. They used limestone discs called rai stones. The Yap didn’t actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with coins, because rai stones could be quite massive. The largest was about four tons and twelve feet across. So the Yap simply kept track of who owned which part of each stone. There’s a story about some sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered trouble, and the stone actually fell in.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession—or risk a public hanging? This was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor—and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem. Battles with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not yet able to print complex organs, but simpler tissues—including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange—are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

Good afternoon, I'm proud to be here at TEDxKrakow. I'll try to speak a little today about a phenomenon that can, and actually is, changing the world—whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are Monty Python lovers, a Monty Python-type sketch. Here it is.  

It is December 15, 2010. Someone gives you a bet: you will look into a crystal ball, and you will see the future—the future will be accurate. But you must share it with the world. Okay, curiosity killed the cat—you take the bet, you look into the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national TV, on a top show, and you tell the story.

We're going to begin in 1964. Bob Dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate. But there's a small minority of dissenters who claim that Bob Dylan is stealing other people's songs.  

2004. Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes The Beatles' *White Album*, combines it with Jay-Z's *The Black Album*, and creates *The Grey Album*. *The Grey Album* becomes an immediate sensation online, and The Beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Now, *The Grey Album* is a remix.

Well, that’s a fairly obvious statement up there. I began with that sentence about 12 years ago, and I started in the context of developing countries, but you’re sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, I believe you’ll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, 'These are places where good teachers won’t go.' On top of that, those are the places trouble comes from. So we have an ironic problem—good teachers don’t want to go to just those places where they’re needed the most. I started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in New Delhi.

Currently, most refugees live in cities rather than in refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees residing in urban areas, there is a pressing need for a paradigm shift and new approaches. Instead of wasting money on building walls, it would be better to invest in programs that help refugees become self-sufficient. (Applause) We always have to leave behind our possessions, but not our skills and knowledge. If given the opportunity to live productive lives, refugees can support themselves and contribute to their host country's development. I was born in the city of Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.

I have two questions for you. First: whose shoulders do you stand on? And second: what do you stand for? These are the two questions I always begin my poetry workshops with students because, at times, poetry can seem like a dead art form for old white men who appear as if they were born to be old—like Benjamin Button or something. I ask my students these two questions, and then I share how I answer them, which is in these three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These are words I repeat like a mantra before every poetry performance. In fact, I was doing it in the corner over there—making faces.

(Laughter) Hello.  

I painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, I handed them a flower—and some intense eye contact. And if they didn’t take the flower, I added a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, ignited a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was not actually the first piece of human technology to enter space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of World War II. It wasn't very effective, but by the war's end, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. had captured the technology—along with the scientists who developed it—and began using them for their own projects.

I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by my attachment to an iPod—an iPod that contains Wagner and Mozart, pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin, concerti, symphonies, and more. I'm a voracious reader, one who enjoys everything from Ian McEwan to Stephanie Meyer. I have read the Twilight tetralogy. And I live for my home theater, where I devour DVDs, video on demand, and plenty of television. For me, it's "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey and "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy"—"the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.

Citizens of the world, we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale. Please stand by for a message from the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres.  

The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and people everywhere.  

So I’m pleased you are launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now enter this race with political will and energy.

Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? As I speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you that it's exhausting. It's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuff it into your pocket in the middle of a class, and rush to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is located in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world—Canada's boreal forest. It stretches across northern Canada, including Labrador, which is home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd on Earth: the George River caribou herd, with approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when I was there, I couldn’t spot a single one, but the antlers serve as proof.  

Across the boreal region, we’re blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are among the most endangered ecosystems. They are absolutely vital—they purify air and water, sequester vast amounts of greenhouse gases, and support a rich diversity of species.

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other—they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers sneaked into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.

So, I had graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and I had gone to a career fair here on campus, where I'd gotten an interview with a startup called Theranos. This meant you wouldn’t need a large needle stuck in your arm to get blood tests done. It was interesting not only because it was less painful but also because it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.

My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old, when my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There we lived with the Inuit in a tiny community of 200 people, where we were one of three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn’t have a television, computers, or even a radio. We didn’t even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the Inuit, playing. The snow and ice were my sandbox, and the Inuit were my teachers. That’s where I became truly obsessed with this polar realm.

I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft—to escort and land the probe on a comet. This has been my passion for the past two years. To do that, I need to explain something about the origin of the solar system. When we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our Sun formed and ignited. Along with it, what we now know as planets, comets, and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when Earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted Earth and delivered water to it. Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. But over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, and some becomes fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
